page.title: 09TRANSPORT IN CHIRNSIDE
page.content: It is very difficult to provide good transport in a rural area. First of all there are not, according to the local people, enough buses. Eighty per cent of the people interviewed in Chirnside have cars, and are unanimous that the price of petrol, which they can buy at 3 of the 4 garages, is too expensive at Â£2.06 per gallon. Nevertheless buses are necessary for the workers. There was once a railway in Chirnside but in 1948 a flood washed away part of the line. Services were suspended for 11 weeks. In 1951 the passenger service stopped but the goods service continued until 1966. This leaves Chirnside with the public buses and privately owned transport services.
